I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Effective infrastructure regulation is vital for delivering water and energy services of an 
appropriate quality and cost to consumers and for ensuring that investing in infrastructure is 
attractive to the private sector. Water and energy infrastructure underpins the delivery of basic 
services that are essential for pro-poor development1 and infrastructure development is a focus 
area in the medium-term strategy II (2006–2008) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).2 Over 
the past two decades, ADB’s developing member countries (DMCs) have undertaken significant 
regulatory  reform  of  infrastructure  and  utility  service  delivery.  However,  despite  recent 
improvements,  in  many  developing  countries  in  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region  the  operating 
efficiency and quality of infrastructure still lag behind international standards. Underlying policy, 
institutional, and regulatory frameworks need to be established and to be operating well.  
 
2.  In 1997, ADB conducted a regional technical assistance (RETA) project on Governance 
and  Regulatory  Regimes  for  Private  Infrastructure  Development3 to  assess  the  impact  of 
governance4 and regulatory reforms in several Asian countries.5 This RETA is still a leading 
source of information on governance and regulatory regimes in Asia and one of only a few 
comparative studies of regulatory institutions in Asia. Since 1997, the academic and policy 
literature has expanded as has ADB’s operational experience with policies, institutions, and 
regulation. ADB and its DMCs recognize there is a need for further analysis of successful and 
unsuccessful regulation in DMCs.  Building on the 1997 RETA, and on subsequent work by 
ADB and other development partners, this RETA6 further investigates the formal and informal 
attributes of effective regulatory reform and governance in Asia through investigating regulatory 
reform in selected DMCs. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Over the past two decades, Asia’s developing countries have undertaken varying levels 
of regulatory reform. The first wave of reforms has produced mixed results, for which various 
reasons  have  been  attributed.  These  reasons  include  that  (i)  models  of  pricing  and  “best 
regulation” from developed countries and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and 
Development (OECD) were often transplanted in developing countries without full consideration 
of the different contexts; (ii)  many policy and governance reform processes were incomplete 
and  measures  designed  to  be  transitional  became  end-points;  (iii)  regulators  were  not 
independent  and  even  “credible”  regulation  was  difficult  to  achieve;  (iv)  implementation  of 
reforms was hindered by poor governance; (v) the institutional context was not conducive to 
reform and regulatory issues were often more complex than in OECD countries;7 (vi) capacity

was very weak and resources were limited.  There is broad agreement8 on the attributes of 
effective  regulation,  which  includes  clarity  of  roles  and  objectives,  autonomy,  participation, 
accountability, transparency, predictability, non-discrimination, proportionality, requisite powers, 
appropriate institutional characteristics, and integrity.9 In evaluating these, both formal attributes 
(such as the design of the regulatory framework) and informal attributes (such as the way the 
framework works in practice) must be considered. Less attention has been paid to date on 
informal attributes of regulatory frameworks. 
 
4.  In evaluating the effectiveness of a regulatory framework, both regulatory governance 
and  regulatory  substance  must  be  considered.10 Regulatory  governance  is  the  “how”  of 
regulation─it deals with the legal design of the regulatory system, the institutional arrangements 
and  the  process  of  regulatory  decision  making.  Regulatory  substance  is  the  “what”  of 
regulation─it  involves  decisions  on  tariffs,  quality,  accounting,  investment,  and  social 
obligations.11 The objective of good regulatory governance is good regulatory substance─to 
have  competent  and  credible  regulatory  decisions.  Thus,  both  regulatory  governance  and 
regulatory substance are intertwined in achieving effective regulation and regulatory reform.  
 
5.  Some work has already been done to assess regulatory effectiveness in Asian countries. 
An  informal  survey  of  East  Asian  and  Pacific  utility  regulators  for  the  Fourth  Asia-Pacific 
Economic Cooperation (APEC) Privatization Forum in 2003 revealed that East Asian regulators 
face issues that are harder to resolve than those in developed countries and that they have to 
address them with less capacity and fewer resources.12 The Asian Development Bank Institute 
(ADBI) reached a similar conclusion in a 2004 paper on Infrastructure Regulation: Models for 
Developing  Asia.13   It  recommended  further  research  into  (i)  the  nature  of  information 
asymmetries within Asian developing economies and how these may be addressed, (ii) the role 
of incentives in different regulatory regimes and lessons learned, (iii) the rationale for regulatory 
practice and the comparative roles of market failure and political capture, (iv) the extent to which 
“good” regulation can be realistically achieved in a developing country and the implications for 
regulatory reform, (v) optimal regulatory structures (and the relevance of independent regulation 
where capacity is weak), (vi) the relationship between utility regulation and broader regulatory 
processes, and (vii) the need for capacity building and the form this should take.  
 
6.  In 2005, a survey of consumer participation in infrastructure regulation in East Asia and 
the  Pacific  was  conducted  by  the  World  Bank. 14  This  survey  considered  (i)  whether 
infrastructure  regulation  in  the  region  met  the  main  institutional  requirements  for  effective 
consumer  participation,  (ii)  whether  regulators  were  performing  their  functions  vis-à-vis

involve  consumers  in  the  regulatory  process,  and  (iv)  whether  regulators  had  in  place 
mechanisms to involve the poor in the regulatory process. The survey was based upon formal 
attributes of the systems and the response of regulators and not on the views of consumers or 
on-the-ground research. A study in 2007 did report on consumer perspectives, but more needs 
to be done in this regard.15 In 2006, the World Bank made a significant contribution to research 
by publishing a handbook with an analytical framework for conducting practical case studies of 
regulatory systems.16 There is a need to apply this framework to actual regulatory systems in 
Asia.  
 
7.  Most of the extensive analysis of infrastructure regulation has been at a theoretical and 
policy level. There have been few case studies that can be used in a practical way to improve 
infrastructure and utility service regulation in Asian DMCs. Of the case studies that do exist, 
including those in the earlier ADB RETA, most have focused on the formal aspects of the 
regulatory frameworks (i.e., on formal laws, regulations, rules, structures, and tariff-setting) and 
their  impact  on  overall  regulatory  reform.  There  has  not  been  enough  assessment  of  the 
informal attributes of regulatory frameworks (i.e. how they work in practice) and the perspectives 
of private sector investors, consumers, and the poor on the effectiveness of regulatory systems 
have not been taken sufficiently into account. 
 
8.  Effective regulation is limited by the formal lack of legal frameworks. Informal attributes 
that  also  act  as  obstacles  to  effective  regulation  in  DMCs  include  information  asymmetry, 
market failure, political capture, weak capacity, and ineffective consumer participation. There is 
a  need  for  further  detailed  investigation  of  these  obstacles,  including  how  and  why  these 
obstacles persist and the impact of regulatory systems on policy makers, consumers, and 
investors. Results can feed into the governance, institutional, and corruption risk assessments 
for the water and energy sectors in the DMCs.17   
 
9.  There has not been enough analysis in Asia of the need to (i) ensure infrastructure 
service delivery to poor consumers, and (ii) reflect clean energy and energy efficiency issues in 
the regulatory reform models that have already been adopted. The quality and experience of the 
regulators is another factor that is often overlooked. Regulatory systems with good policies, 
strong government commitment, and intense concern for consumers and investors may still fail 
because of a lack of capacity. Finally, the question of whether it is possible to have effective 
regulatory agencies in countries without effective consumer representation or active and vigilant 
civil society groups needs to be addressed. The lessons from the 1997 RETA and the work 
done  by  ADB  and  others  is  that  a  systematic  comparative  case  study  that  evaluates  the 
effectiveness of formal and informal attributes of regulatory systems is required to define the 
contours of further reform.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of this RETA is expected to be improved design and implementation of water 
and energy sector reforms by DMCs and their development partners (including ADB) as a result 
of an improved understanding of the effectiveness of the water and energy regulatory reforms 
so far undertaken. The outcome of this RETA will be to identify and publish institutional and 
technical  factors  influencing  the  effectiveness  of  water  and  energy  regulatory  reforms 
undertaken in selected DMCs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The methodology for conducting the RETA will involve literature reviews and case-study 
investigations into the formal and informal attributes of water and energy regulation in several 
DMCs, which shall employ modes such as survey questionnaires of existing and potential 
private investors in water and energy infrastructure, DMC citizens and consumers of water and 
energy utility services, and DMC government officials. The following criteria will be used to 
select the DMCs for the case studies: (i) the countries should have a regulatory framework for 
the water and energy sectors; (ii) regulatory data should be available; and (iii) there should be a 
representative mix of countries, reflecting economic and cultural diversity, and there should be a 
balance between subregions. 
 
12.  The  key  activities  will  be  (i)  a  literature  survey  of  issues  relating  to  infrastructure 
regulation and its reform; (ii) a review of ADB’s experience in relevant DMCs; (iii) field research 
into formal and informal policies and the institutional and regulatory frameworks in several 
DMCs; (iv) at least one workshop per DMC to solicit views from stakeholders; (v) external and 
internal peer review of the draft report of findings; (vi) workshops involving ADB staff to explain 
the  findings  of  the  RETA  and  to  consider  their  relevance  for  ADB’s  operational  work  in 
infrastructure policy; (vii) broad dissemination of the results of the investigation through written 
and web-based publications and workshops involving DMC officials, consumers, and investors; 
and (viii) strengthening of a series of ADB knowledge products currently being prepared. 
 
13.  The  findings  will  seek  to  expand  and  deepen  ADB’s  knowledge  of  infrastructure 
regulation and to produce publications that share this knowledge within ADB, with DMCs, and 
with other development partners. In disseminating the results, ADB will seek to use and build on 
such networks as the East Asia and Pacific Infrastructure Regulatory Forum, the South Asia 
Forum  of  Infrastructure  Regulators,  the  Central  Asian  Regional  Economic  Cooperation  on 
Infrastructure,  and  the  Public-Private  Infrastructure  Advisory  Facility,  to  which  ADB  is  a 
contributor.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The RETA is estimated to cost $564,000, to be financed by ADB on a grant basis from 
ADB’s TA funding program. This amount will finance the research, workshops, consultants, and 
publication of the report. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB, through the Office of the General Counsel (OGC), will be the Executing Agency for 
and will be responsible for overall management and monitoring of activities. The counterpart 
agencies  in  the  participating  DMCs  will  be  identified  by  OGC  in  conjunction  with  ADB’s 
operations departments.18 OGC will collaborate with and coordinate departments involved in the 
provision of infrastructure as well as with the ADB communities of practice for water and energy 
and the Regional Sustainable Infrastructure Division (RSID). OGC is currently collaborating with 
RSID on various energy and water-related projects. OGC will also coordinate with the ADB 
Institute, the World Bank, and other development partners.  
 
16.  All  consulting  services  for  the  project  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time).  It is estimated that 
up to 32 person-months of consulting services will be required, of which 8 person-months will be 
performed by international consultants and 24 person-months by national consultants. These 
consultants  will  be  recruited  through  a  firm  following  quality-  and  cost-based  selection 
procedures on the basis of bio-data proposals. In addition, resource persons will be recruited for 
2.5 person-months to conduct a peer review and to assist ADB. Consultants will work closely 
with specialists in the operations departments and resident missions of the participating DMCs 
and designated government counterparts. The outline terms of reference of consultants are in 
Appendix 3. 
 
17.  The RETA will be implemented over 15 months, starting in April 2008 and ending in July 
2009. The consultants will submit inception, progress, draft final, and final reports. The outline of 
the final report is in Appendix 4. The consultants will organize (i) one workshop for each 
participating DMC to solicit views from stakeholders; (ii) one workshop for each participating 
DMC to discuss the findings; (iii) one regional workshop to discuss the draft final report, share 
practical information on the challenges faced in establishing effective regulation, and identify 
key areas for improvement of water and energy regulatory reforms; and (iv) two or three 
workshops at ADB to discuss the findings with relevant ADB staff. Reporting requirements for 
the consultants are as follows: (i) an inception report within 4 weeks of RETA commencement; 
(ii) individual country reports, including summaries of proceedings of national workshops; (iii) a 
draft  final  report  at  least  1  month  before  the  regional  workshop;  and  (iv)  a  final  report 
summarizing the outputs with an appropriately documented list of the achievements.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $564,000 on a grant basis for 
Enhancing Effective Regulation of Water and Energy Infrastructure and Utility Services, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
18  Any activity funded by this RETA will begin only after ADB has received a statement of no-objection in writing from 
the government of the DMC concerned.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The regional technical assistance (RETA) will be carried out by a team of international and 
national consultants. Up to 32 person-months of consulting services will be required, of which 8 
person-months will be performed by international consultants, and 24 person-months by national 
consultants. In addition, resource persons will be recruited to conduct a 2.5 person-month peer 
review.  
 
A.  Consultants Recruited as Firm 
 
2.  ADB will recruit a firm or institution to provide 8 person-months of international consulting 
services and 24 person-months national consulting services.  
 
3.  The international consultants will be engaged to (i) conduct a literature review of water and 
energy  regulation  and  its  reform,  including  public  interest  and  public  policy  issues  and  best 
practices; (ii) identify gaps in the empirical evidence to be filled by undertaking country case 
studies;  (iii)  design,  coordinate,  and  supervise  the  preparation  of  country  case  studies;  and  
(iv)  prepare  an  overall  report  of  findings.  The  international  consultants  will  have  a  strong 
background in and experience of water and/or energy regulation and governance in the Asia and 
Pacific region. They should preferably have working experience in at least two of the participating 
countries. They should have a good understanding of water and/or energy regulation issues in 
developing countries. The main tasks of the international consultants will include: 
 
(i)  reviewing existing literature, data, and studies to identify the present state of 
knowledge on effective regulation of water and energy infrastructure and utility 
services; 
 
(ii)  holding  discussions  with  staff  of  ADB  and  other  international  development 
agencies  to  review  current  policies  in  infrastructure  and  utility  services 
regulation; 
 
(iii)  preparing  an  inception  report  outlining  the  overall  conceptualization  of  the 
RETA,  proposed  approach,  methodology,  work  plan  and  schedule,  detailed 
terms  of  reference  for  team  members,  and  management  and  coordination 
arrangements; 
 
(iv)  preparing  a  preliminary  conceptual  framework  to  represent  how  regulatory 
governance and regulatory substance contribute to effective regulation of water 
and energy;  
 
(v)  evaluating  the  adequacy  of  existing  regulatory  frameworks  and  empirical 
evidence  for  identifying  best  practice  of  regulation  in  water  and  energy 
infrastructure and utility services; 
 
(vi)  reviewing  any  specific  mechanisms  in  the  existing  regulatory  framework  to 
ensure infrastructure service delivery to the poor; 
 
(vii)  reviewing any incentive mechanisms in the existing regulatory framework for 
promoting clean energy and energy efficiency;

4.  National consultants will be required in each of the DMCs selected for case studies. They 
will have experience in law and infrastructure regulation, both in energy or water, and in legal and 
institutional matters. They will work as a team. A willingness to discuss previous experience will be 
important. The team of consultants should have a multidisciplinary background and a thorough 
understanding of their respective countries. They must be willing to conduct field work. They must 
be fluent in English and the language of the countries they work in.  Experience in organizing and 
facilitating  workshops  will  be  an  asset.  The  national  consultants  will  work  under  the  direct 
supervision of the international consultants and their main task will be to: 
 
(i)  help prepare a proposed approach and detailed methodology for conducting the 
case studies; 
 
(ii)  provide expertise in water and/or energy infrastructure regulation to assist in the 
selection of case studies and design methodology; 
 
(iii)  obtain water and/or energy infrastructure regulation data for use in case studies; 
 
(iv)  organize and conduct two national workshops in participating DMCs, the first to 
consult with all relevant stakeholders and the second to present country findings 
to stakeholders and obtain their feedback before finalizing country reports; 
 
(v)  coordinate the process of selecting case studies, taking into account the views 
of key national agencies concerned with water and energy infrastructure and 
utility services regulation, and review and compile information related to water 
and/or energy regulation in participating DMCs; 
 
(vi)  coordinate  and  carry  out  the  case  studies  and/or  surveys,  including  field 
research, of the formal and informal policy, and of the institutional and regulatory 
framework in selected DMCs; 
 
(vii)  conduct interview-based research to identify the nature and extent of effective 
regulation in water and energy infrastructure and utility services; 
 
(viii)  produce a country report for each participating DMC, covering (a) an analysis of 
formal infrastructure regulation policies, including laws, rules, structure and tariff-
setting; (b) an analysis of the informal attributes of regulation; (c) an analysis of 
the  perspectives  of  private  sector  investors,  consumers  and  the  poor  in 
determining the effectiveness of regulatory systems; and (d) recommendations 
for future ADB operations through policy dialogue, TA, and loans; 
 
(ix)  produce an analytical report for each participating DMC, covering the existing 
regulatory framework for (a) pro-poor infrastructure regulation, (b) clean energy 
and energy efficiency, and (c) recommendations for future assistance and policy 
support in these areas;  
 
(x)  plan and manage regional, national, and in-house workshops and present the 
findings of the country case studies; and

B.  Resource Persons 
 
5.  One or more resource persons may be recruited for up to 2.5 person-months for peer 
review input and to assist ADB at different stages of the RETA. The main tasks of the resource 
persons may include: 
 
(i)  reviewing  the  inception  report,  outlining  the  overall  conceptualization  of  the 
RETA, the proposed approach, methodology, work plan and schedule, detailed 
terms  of  reference  for  team  members,  and  management  and  coordination 
arrangements; 
 
(ii)  reviewing the criteria for participating DMCs and the shortlist for DMC case 
studies; 
 
(iii)  reviewing the report presenting findings on the state of knowledge about how 
regulatory frameworks work in practice, the identified gaps, proposed choice of 
countries and subjects for case studies, and outline terms of reference for the 
case studies; 
 
(iv)  reviewing the design and methodology of case studies and research instruments 
to ensure consistency; 
 
(v)  reviewing the survey instrument to be used in country case studies to obtain the 
opinions  of  key  government  officials  and  policy  makers,  stakeholders,  and 
consumers on the effectiveness of regulation of water and energy infrastructure 
and utility services;  
 
(vi)  reviewing  the  report  prepared  by  consultants  including  (a)  country  reports 
prepared for the regional conference and submitted by the national consultants, 
(b)  proceedings  and  discussions  of  the  regional  workshop,  and  
(c) recommendations for ADB;  
 
(vii)  advising ADB on pro-poor infrastructure regulation and consumer protection; 
 
(viii)  advising  ADB  on  issues  relating  to  regulatory  incentives  to  promote  clean 
energy and energy efficiency; and  
 
(ix)  reviewing the ADB publication on enhancing effective regulation of water and 
energy infrastructure services.
